title: 108_hr1819
content: The Act is titled the "Poison Control Center Enhancement and Awareness Act Amendments of 2003". Section 2 of the Act is amended to include new findings. "Congress acknowledges the vital role of poison control centers in preventing injury and deaths from poisoning, with millions of poison exposures annually. Children under 6 account for over 50% of these exposures, leading to hospitalizations, acute care, and fatalities." The funding and accessibility of poison control centers are crucial in reducing inappropriate use of emergency services. The events of September 11, 2001, highlighted the importance of poison centers in providing accurate medical information during crises. The War on Terrorism recommended using Poison Control Centers for public education on biological, chemical, and nuclear terrorism. Increased demand during terrorist events will raise call volume. SEC. 3 amends the Poison Control Enhancement and Awareness Act to maintain a national toll-free number. SEC. 4 focuses on a nationwide media campaign to promote poison control center utilization. SEC. 5 establishes a poison control center grant program. SEC. 5 amends the Poison Control Enhancement and Awareness Act to maintain a poison control center grant program. The Poison Control Enhancement and Awareness Act is amended to include provisions for developing standardized poison prevention programs, patient management guidelines, data collection systems, toxic exposure surveillance, toxicologic expertise, and crisis response capacity within poison control centers. Additionally, the Secretary is granted the authority to renew waivers as needed. The Secretary is authorized to renew waivers under the Poison Control Enhancement and Awareness Act, with a limit of 5 years total. Additionally, funding is increased to $30,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. SEC. 7. Nationwide toxicosurveillance of poison center data to promote hazard detection is added to the Poison Control Enhancement and Awareness Act. The Secretary will assist in national toxicosurveillance of poison control center data to detect hazards from toxic substances. They may contract professional organizations for data collection and analysis in real time. $2,500,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2005 through 2009.
